text: this Dutch baby is like Yorkshire
pudding meets a popover meets a skillet
pancake but with a savory personality so
you can use any kind of herbs that you
like
I've got thyme and then I have some
chives over here but you know it works
really well basil parsley fresh oregano
so use whatever you have this kind of
pancake needs lots of eggs because eggs
are what gives it its rise so when you
pull it out of the oven the whole thing
puffs up and it's absolutely gorgeous
it's all because of the eggs this Dutch
baby satisfies that same quiche urge you
know when you want a piece of quiche but
you're not gonna make a quiche I know
you know those moments with nothing but
key she will do whenever you're mixing
up dry and wet ingredients for something
like a pancake or a cake you always do
them separately you want to get that dry
really well mixed and you want to get
the wet really well mixed and then when
you mix them together it just combines
more easily and you don't have to stir
it as much so you just want to mix this
until it's pretty smooth but it doesn't
have to be perfectly smooth you just
don't want any big lumps because if
there's a big lump and you're gonna get
a mouthful of flour and that's not
pleasant it's not traditional to brown
the butter and a Dutch baby usually you
just melt the butter but browning it
adds an extra layer of flavor it gives
it this nutty scent you're going to hear
sizzle sizzle sizzle and that's the
water being cooked out of the butter
once it quiets down you know that you're
almost there
most Dutch babies are sweet they're
often made with fruit you put maple
syrup on top but this one is savory
however if you wanted to make a sweet
version of it leave out the cheese leave
out the herbs and then just add a little
bit of sugar you can serve this for
breakfast you can serve it for brunch
with some bacon or you can serve it for
dinner just add a little salad just to
complete the meal
Oh
